title: Visa Validation (VLS-TS)
label: Immigration
description: Register your long-stay student visa online with the ANEF.

detailedInfo.overview: All international students with a long-stay visa (VLS-TS) must validate it online within 3 months of arriving in France. This validation is essential for your legal stay in France and replaces the physical OFII stamp that was previously required.
detailedInfo.discussion: The ANEF (Administration Numérique pour les Étrangers en France) platform has digitalized the visa validation process, making it more accessible for international students. This procedure is critical as it officially starts your legal residence period in France. Without this validation, your visa is not considered valid, and you may face legal issues if you need to travel outside France and return. The process is entirely online, which means you can complete it from the comfort of your accommodation once you have a French address. The validation fee is mandatory and must be paid online using a credit or debit card. After successful validation, you will receive a confirmation that serves as proof of your legal status in France.
steps: Prepare a valid French address (rental agreement, accommodation certificate, or host attestation)
Visit the ANEF website at administration-etrangers-en-france.interieur.gouv.fr
Create an account using your email address and personal information
Select "Validate my VLS-TS visa" option
Fill out the online form with your passport and visa details
Upload scanned copies of your passport (photo page and visa page)
Upload proof of your French address
Upload a recent digital passport photo
Pay the validation fee (currently €70-80) using a credit/debit card
Submit your application
Receive confirmation email (usually within 24-48 hours)
Download and save your validation certificate
requiredDocuments: Valid passport with VLS-TS visa sticker
Proof of French address (rental agreement, accommodation certificate, or host attestation)
Digital passport-style photo (recent, color, neutral background)
Credit or debit card for payment
tips: Complete this as soon as you arrive and have a French address - don"t wait until the last minute
Save multiple copies of your validation confirmation (digital and printed)
This validation is your proof of legal residence - keep it with your passport
If you plan to travel outside France during your studies, ensure your visa is validated before leaving
The ANEF platform may experience high traffic during peak enrollment periods (September-October)
Contact your university"s international office if you encounter technical issues

title: University Enrollment & CVEC
label: Academic
description: Finalize your academic registration and pay the mandatory Campus and Student Life Contribution.
shortSummary: Complete enrollment and pay €100-110 CVEC fee

detailedInfo.overview: University enrollment is your official registration as an EPITA student, and the CVEC (Contribution Vie Étudiante et de Campus) is a mandatory annual contribution that funds student life services, health services, and campus facilities.
detailedInfo.discussion: The CVEC was introduced in 2018 to support student life and well-being on French campuses. This contribution funds various services including cultural activities, sports facilities, psychological support services, and social assistance. Payment is mandatory for all students enrolling in French higher education institutions. You must pay the CVEC before completing your university enrollment, as you will need to present the CVEC attestation during the registration process. The payment is done through a dedicated government platform, and the attestation you receive is valid for the entire academic year. Keep this attestation safe as you may need to present it multiple times throughout the year.
steps: Visit the CVEC website at cvec.etudiant.gouv.fr
Create an account or log in with your existing credentials
Fill out your personal information and select EPITA as your institution
Pay the CVEC contribution (€100 for 2024-2025)
Download your CVEC attestation immediately
Contact EPITA"s admissions office to schedule your enrollment appointment
Gather all required enrollment documents
Attend your enrollment appointment with all documents including CVEC attestation
Complete administrative formalities and sign enrollment contract
Receive your student card and university credentials
Activate your EPITA email and online student portal access
requiredDocuments: Proof of health insurance (will be addressed in Social Security registration)
tips: Pay the CVEC as soon as you receive your acceptance letter
Save multiple copies of your CVEC attestation - both digital and printed
Your CVEC attestation is valid for one academic year and must be renewed annually
Students from EU/EEA countries and certain scholarship holders may be exempt from CVEC
Your EPITA student card provides discounts at museums, cinemas, and restaurants
Activate your student email immediately - this is your official communication channel

title: Social Security Registration
label: Healthcare
description: Register for French national health insurance coverage.
shortSummary: Free healthcare coverage for students in France

detailedInfo.overview: All international students studying in France are automatically affiliated with the French social security system (Sécurité Sociale), which provides healthcare coverage. This is a mandatory registration that gives you access to reimbursement for medical expenses.
detailedInfo.discussion: The French healthcare system is considered one of the best in the world. As a student, you are automatically covered by the social security system at no additional cost. However, the reimbursement rates vary - typically 70% for doctor visits and 60-100% for hospital care. Many students choose to complement this with a mutuelle (complementary health insurance) to cover the remaining costs. The registration process has been streamlined for international students, and you can complete most steps online. Once registered, you will receive a social security number (numéro de sécurité sociale) that is permanent and will remain yours even if you leave and return to France later. The Carte Vitale is your health insurance card that you present to doctors and pharmacies.
steps: Ensure you have completed your university enrollment and have a student certificate
Ensure your VLS-TS visa is validated
Visit etudiant-etranger.ameli.fr
Click 'Create my account' and choose your institution (EPITA)
Fill in your personal information exactly as it appears on official documents
Upload required documents (passport, visa, student certificate, proof of address)
Provide your French bank account details (RIB)
Submit your application
Wait for processing (typically 2-6 weeks)
Receive your social security number by email
Receive your Carte Vitale by mail at your French address (can take 2-3 months)
Download the Ameli mobile app to manage your health insurance
requiredDocuments: Validated VLS-TS visa or residence permit
Proof of French address (rental agreement or accommodation certificate)
French bank account details (RIB) - see procedure "Open a French Bank Account"
tips: Apply as soon as you have your student certificate and validated visa
Your social security number is permanent - write it down and keep it safe
While waiting for your Carte Vitale, you can still see doctors - request paper forms (feuille de soins)
Consider getting complementary insurance (mutuelle) for better coverage - LMDE, SMENO, and MAE offer student rates
The Ameli app allows you to track reimbursements and download attestations
Emergency care is available even without your Carte Vitale - always carry your passport
Prescriptions must be filled at French pharmacies to be reimbursed

title: Open a French Bank Account
label: Financial
description: Essential for daily finances, paying bills, and receiving aid.
shortSummary: Required for CAF, rent, and local transactions
required: Passport/visa, proof of address, student certificate

detailedInfo.overview: Opening a French bank account is essential for managing your finances in France. It is required for receiving housing aid (CAF), paying rent, and many other services. French banks offer special student packages that are often free or low-cost.
detailedInfo.discussion: A French bank account provides you with a RIB (Relevé d"Identité Bancaire), which is your bank account identifier needed for virtually all financial transactions in France. Unlike in some countries, cash and foreign cards are not widely accepted for recurring payments like rent, subscriptions, or receiving aid. The RIB contains your IBAN and is required for setting up direct debits, receiving salary or aid payments, and proving your financial situation. Traditional banks (BNP Paribas, Société Générale, LCL, Crédit Agricole) have physical branches where you can get in-person support, which can be helpful for international students. However, online banks (Boursorama, Hello Bank, N26) often offer faster account opening and no maintenance fees. As an international student, you have the legal right to open a basic bank account in France, even if banks sometimes seem reluctant.
steps: Research banks and compare student offers (many offer free accounts for students)
Choose between traditional banks (with branches) or online banks (faster, digital)
For traditional banks: Book an appointment online or by phone
For online banks: Complete application online with document uploads
Gather all required documents
Attend your appointment (if applicable) or complete online verification
Bring original documents and copies
Sign account opening agreement and terms
Make initial deposit if required (usually €10-50 for traditional banks, often €0 for online)
Receive your RIB immediately (often by email)
Wait for your bank card to arrive by mail (5-10 business days)
Activate your card at an ATM or online
Set up online banking and download mobile app
requiredDocuments: VLS-TS student visa or residence permit
Proof of address in France (rental agreement, accommodation certificate, or utility bill)
Sometimes: proof of enrollment or acceptance letter
tips: Many banks offer free accounts for students under 25-28 years old
Online banks like Boursorama or Hello Bank can open accounts in 5-10 days
N26 is popular among international students but may not be accepted for CAF
Always keep several copies of your RIB - you"ll need it frequently
Some banks require proof of address, which can be a catch-22 - temporary accommodation certificates work
If a bank refuses your application, you can invoke your "droit au compte" (right to an account)
Your bank card may have daily withdrawal and payment limits - check and adjust if needed
Consider keeping a card from your home country for the first month as backup

title: Secure Accommodation & Home Insurance
label: Housing
description: Finalize your rental agreement and obtain mandatory home insurance.
shortSummary: Rental agreement and insurance required by law

detailedInfo.overview: Finding accommodation is one of the first priorities for international students. Once you have secured housing, obtaining home insurance (assurance habitation) is mandatory by French law. You must provide proof of insurance to your landlord before moving in and annually thereafter.
detailedInfo.discussion: The French rental market can be challenging, especially in Paris and major cities. Student accommodation options include CROUS residences (subsidized student housing), private student residences, private rentals, and shared apartments. CROUS housing is the most affordable but has limited availability and long waiting lists. Private student residences are more expensive but often include utilities and internet. Home insurance is mandatory for all tenants in France, and landlords will require proof before handing over keys and annually thereafter. Student home insurance is relatively inexpensive (€30-80/year) and covers damages to the property and your belongings. The move-in inventory (état des lieux) is a crucial document that records the condition of the apartment - take your time and photographs to protect yourself when moving out.
steps: Start searching for accommodation as early as possible (2-3 months before arrival)
Explore options: CROUS (apply via messervices.etudiant.gouv.fr), private student residences, or private rentals
Prepare required documents (student certificate, guarantor, passport)
Visit accommodations if possible, or request virtual tours
Sign your rental agreement (bail) - read it carefully
Obtain home insurance BEFORE move-in date
Compare insurance offers: SMENO, LMDE, MAE, or traditional insurers
Subscribe to insurance online or at an agency
Receive your insurance attestation (attestation d"assurance habitation)
Provide insurance proof to your landlord
Complete move-in inventory (état des lieux d"entrée) with landlord or agent
Take photos of every room and any existing damage
Keep all documentation: lease, insurance, inventory, and correspondence
requiredDocuments: Guarantor documents (if required): French guarantor or Visale guarantee
Proof of income or financial resources
tips: CROUS housing is cheapest (€200-400/month) but apply early - waiting lists are long
Visale is a free government guarantor service for students under 30
Home insurance for students costs around €30-60/year
Always attend the move-in inventory and document everything with photos
Keep your insurance certificate accessible - landlords check it annually
Utilities may or may not be included in rent - clarify this before signing
The notice period is usually 1-3 months - check your lease
Shared apartments (colocation) can be more affordable and social

title: Apply for CAF Housing Aid (APL)
label: Financial Aid
description: Government financial assistance to help reduce rent costs.
timeConstraint: Apply as soon as you have housing and bank account

detailedInfo.overview: CAF (Caisse d"Allocations Familiales) provides housing assistance (APL or ALS) to students and low-income individuals. This can significantly reduce your monthly rent by €50-200 or more, depending on your situation, rent amount, and location.
detailedInfo.discussion: CAF is a government organization that provides various social benefits, including housing assistance. The APL (Aide Personnalisée au Logement) is calculated based on your rent, location, income, and living situation. Most international students qualify for assistance, even if they receive financial support from parents or scholarships abroad. The application process can be lengthy (2-3 months for first payment), but payments are backdated to your application date, so apply as soon as possible. You will need to provide annual updates with new student certificates and proof of enrollment. The aid is paid directly to you (not the landlord) and you must still pay full rent to your landlord. CAF requires specific documentation and has strict requirements - incomplete applications cause delays.
steps: Ensure you have a French bank account and signed rental agreement
Visit www.caf.fr
Click 'Faire une demande de prestation' (Apply for benefits)
Create an account with your personal details
Fill out the housing assistance application (APL or ALS)
Provide detailed information about your accommodation
Upload all required documents
Submit your landlord"s information (name, address, RIB)
Submit the application
Wait for CAF to review (can take 2-3 months)
Respond promptly to any requests for additional information
Receive notification of decision
Set up direct deposit to your French bank account
Receive first payment (backdated to application date)
Remember to update CAF every year with new student certificate
requiredDocuments: Copy of passport or national ID
Proof of resources (or declaration of zero income if parents support you)
tips: Apply immediately after moving in - aid is paid from application date, not approval date
Even if your parents support you financially, you can still qualify
Use the CAF simulator on their website to estimate your aid amount
Payments go to you, not your landlord - budget accordingly
You must update CAF every year with a new student certificate
CROUS housing and some private residences are automatically reported to CAF
Keep copies of all correspondence and documents sent to CAF
If sharing an apartment, each person can apply for their share
Processing time is long - don"t expect money in the first 2-3 months

title: Get a Navigo Pass
label: Transportation
description: Monthly/weekly pass for unlimited travel on Paris public transport.
shortSummary: Unlimited metro, bus, RER travel for ~€40/month (under 26)

detailedInfo.overview: The Navigo pass is a rechargeable smart card that provides unlimited travel on all public transportation in Paris and Île-de-France, including metro, bus, RER, tram, and Transilien trains. Students under 26 benefit from significant discounts.
detailedInfo.discussion: The Navigo system is the primary transportation card for Paris residents. For students under 26, the Imagine R subscription offers unlimited travel across all zones for approximately €40/month (pricing varies by zones and your age). This is significantly cheaper than buying individual tickets (€2.10 per ticket). The card requires a one-time purchase fee (€5) and can be recharged monthly or annually. If you"re over 26, you can still get a regular Navigo pass with monthly or weekly subscriptions. The zones system determines pricing: Paris is in zones 1-2, and most suburbs extend to zones 3-5. EPITA"s main campus in Le Kremlin-Bicêtre is accessible via metro line 7, so zones 1-2 or 1-3 usually suffice. You can reload your pass at ticket machines in metro stations, online via the Île-de-France Mobilités website, or through the mobile app.
steps: Prepare a recent passport-style photo (digital or printed)
Go to any major metro or RER station ticket counter (guichet)
Fill out the application form with your name and photo
Choose your subscription type: Imagine R (under 26), weekly, monthly, or annual, always check for any discounts, and how to fulfill them.
If choosing Imagine R, provide student certificate
Pay for your first subscription period
Receive your card immediately
Download the Île-de-France Mobilités app for easy recharging
Reload your pass before it expires (monthly passes must be recharged between the 20th of previous month and 19th of current month)
requiredDocuments: For Imagine R: student certificate from EPITA
tips: If you"re under 26, Imagine R is the best deal at ~€40/month for all zones
Annual Imagine R subscription offers 2 months free
If over 26, consider the weekly Navigo if you won"t use it daily
You can reload online or at stations - set up automatic recharge to avoid forgetting
Always carry your Navigo - inspectors fine heavily for fare dodging (€50+)
The card is transferable between types of subscriptions
Monthly Navigo can only be loaded from the 20th of the previous month
Night buses (Noctilien) are included in your Navigo subscription

title: Join Student Associations
label: Social
description: Connect with other students, discover activities, and make friends.
shortSummary: Great for networking, making friends, and cultural integration

detailedInfo.overview: French universities and grandes écoles have a rich tradition of student associations (associations étudiantes) covering sports, culture, technology, international students, and specific interests. These are excellent opportunities for socializing, networking, and cultural integration.
detailedInfo.discussion: Student associations are an integral part of French higher education culture. At EPITA, there are numerous associations focusing on computer science, robotics, gaming, sports, music, and international students. Joining associations helps you meet both French and international students, practice French, develop skills outside academics, and build your professional network. Many associations organize events, competitions, trips, and workshops. Some are purely social, while others are professional and can help with internships and job opportunities. Association membership fees are typically affordable (€5-30/year), and participating is one of the best ways to make your student experience memorable.
steps: Check EPITA"s official list of student associations on their website or BDE (student office)
Attend the associations fair (Forum des Associations) at the start of the academic year
Browse association stands and talk to current members
Identify associations that match your interests (tech clubs, sports, culture, international)
Join association group chats or social media pages
Pay membership fee (usually €5-30)
Attend initial meetings and events
Participate actively and contribute to association activities
Consider taking on responsibilities or leadership roles
tips: The BDE (Bureau des Élèves) is the main student organization - they coordinate events and activities
ESN (Erasmus Student Network) helps international students integrate
Tech-focused associations at EPITA often work on real projects - great for your resume
Sports associations (AS) offer activities at reduced student rates
Cultural associations organize trips to museums, concerts, and events around France
Don"t be shy - associations are very welcoming to international students
Language exchange programs help you practice French with native speakers
Participating in associations is a great way to practice French in informal settings

title: Learn French consistently
label: Language
description: Essential language skills for daily life and administrative tasks. You will need it for mastering the Final French Exam before graduating.
shortSummary: Improves daily life, required for many administrative tasks

detailedInfo.overview: While many people in Paris speak English, learning basic French significantly improves your daily life, helps with administrative procedures, and is essential for cultural integration. Many offices, shops, and services prefer or require French communication.
detailedInfo.discussion: French language skills are valuable not just for academic success but for navigating daily life in France. While Paris is international and many people speak English, administrative offices, banks, housing agencies, and healthcare providers often operate primarily in French. Even basic French skills like greetings, numbers, and common phrases will make your life much easier. Starting interactions with 'Bonjour' and attempting French shows respect and often makes people more willing to help. Many French people appreciate the effort even if you make mistakes. Beyond practicality, learning French opens doors to French culture, literature, cinema, and deeper connections with local friends.
steps: Start with basics: greetings (Bonjour, Merci, S"il vous plaît, Au revoir)
Learn numbers, days of the week, and common questions
Use language learning apps: Duolingo, Babbel, or Rosetta Stone
Enroll in EPITA or university French courses (often free for international students)
Check if your university offers FLE (Français Langue Étrangère) classes
Join language exchange programs or conversation groups
Find a language tandem partner (you teach your language, they teach French)
Watch French TV shows and movies with subtitles (Netflix has good French content)
Listen to French podcasts or radio (RFI, France Inter)
Practice daily: order in French at cafés, ask questions in shops
Use language apps like HelloTalk or Tandem to chat with French speakers
Read French news websites with a dictionary handy
requiredDocuments: For some language schools: identity document
tips: Always start conversations with 'Bonjour' - it"s considered rude not to greet
Many universities offer free French courses (FLE) for international students
Language tandems are free and effective - exchange 30 min your language, 30 min French
Don"t be embarrassed to make mistakes - French people appreciate the effort
Basic administrative vocabulary is crucial: loyer (rent), assurance (insurance), rendez-vous (appointment)
The Meetup app has many French-English language exchange groups in Paris
Children"s books and comics (BD) are great for learning - try Tintin or Astérix
French pronunciation is challenging - apps like Forvo help you hear correct pronunciation

title: Get a French Mobile Plan
label: Communication
description: Obtain a French phone number (+33) for administrative 2FA and daily contact.
shortSummary: Essential for bank 2FA and receiving deliveries

detailedInfo.overview: Having a French mobile number is virtually mandatory. Most French banks, the CAF, and online delivery services require a French number (+33) to send Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) codes. Using a foreign number often results in not receiving these critical SMS.
detailedInfo.discussion: France has one of the most competitive mobile markets in the world. Plans are typically 'sans engagement' (no contract commitment), meaning you can cancel at any time. Major operators include Orange, SFR, Bouygues Telecom, and Free Mobile. 'Free Mobile' is particularly popular among students for its low-cost plans with high data caps (often €10-20 for 100GB+). You can sign up online or at kiosks (bornes) in tobacco shops or dedicated stores. You will need a French bank account (RIB) because monthly bills are paid via automatic direct debit (prélèvement).
steps: Compare offers (Free, RED by SFR, Sosh, Bouygues)
Decide if you need a new phone or just a SIM card
Visit a store, a 'Free Center', or the operator's website
Provide your French address and email
Provide your French bank details (RIB) for monthly payment
Pay for the SIM card (usually €10 one-time fee)
Insert SIM and activate (PIN is usually 1234 or 0000 initially)
Update your phone number on your Bank, ANEF, and CAF accounts immediately
requiredDocuments: Debit card for the initial SIM card payment
tips: Look for 'Forfait sans engagement' (no-contract plan)
Free Mobile has automated kiosks (Bornes) where you can get a SIM in 5 minutes
WhatsApp works with your old number, but standard SMS needs the new one
If you want to keep your French number when switching carriers later, you need your RIO code (call 3179)
Check network coverage if you live in a rural area (Orange has best coverage generally)

title: Declare 'Médecin Traitant'
label: Healthcare
description: Designate a primary care physician to ensure maximum reimbursement rates.

detailedInfo.overview: In the French healthcare system, you must declare a 'Médecin Traitant' (referring doctor/GP). If you do not declare one, your reimbursement rate from Social Security drops from 70% to 30% for consultations, known as the 'parcours de soins coordonnés'.
detailedInfo.discussion: A Médecin Traitant is usually a General Practitioner (Généraliste). You should choose one near your accommodation. You are free to choose any doctor, but they must accept new patients. During your first consultation, you simply ask them to become your Médecin Traitant. They will declare it electronically using your Carte Vitale. This doctor will hold your medical records and refer you to specialists (like dermatologists or cardiologists) if needed. Note that Gynecologists, Ophthalmologists, and Psychiatrists can be seen directly without a referral.
steps: Create an account on Doctolib.fr (the standard platform for booking doctors)
Search for 'Médecin Généraliste' near your address
Filter by 'Accepte les nouveaux patients' (Accepts new patients)
Book a consultation (Ex: for a check-up or medical certificate)
Bring your Carte Vitale (or certificate of social security rights)
During the visit, ask: 'Pouvez-vous être mon médecin traitant ?'
The doctor will swipe your card to register the declaration
Verify the declaration appears in your Ameli account under 'Mes informations'
requiredDocuments: Carte Vitale or Attestation de droits
Payment method (Cash or Card - verify beforehand)
tips: Doctors in 'Secteur 1' charge the standard rate (€26.50) fully reimbursable base
Doctors in 'Secteur 2' charge extra fees (dépassements d'honoraires) not covered by basic social security
Doctolib is the easiest way to find English-speaking doctors (filter by language)
If you cannot find a doctor, the 'Médiateur de la CPAM' can help assign one
You can change your Médecin Traitant at any time without justification

title: Subscribe to 'Mutuelle'
label: Insurance
description: Get complementary health insurance to cover the remaining 30% of medical costs.

detailedInfo.overview: Social Security covers about 70% of standard medical costs. A 'Mutuelle' (Complementary Health Insurance) covers the remaining 30% (ticket modérateur) and can cover expensive items like dental, optical, and hospitalization which are poorly reimbursed by the state.
detailedInfo.discussion: While not legally mandatory like Home Insurance, a Mutuelle is financially vital. A single day in a hospital can cost hundreds of euros without one. For students, specific mutuals (LMDE, HEYME) offer low-cost packages starting at €10-15/month. If you have very low income, you might be eligible for the 'Complémentaire Santé Solidaire' (CSS), which is free or costs less than €1/day. Most student mutuelles also include Civil Liability insurance (Responsabilité Civile), which is often required for internships.
steps: Assess your medical needs (Do you wear glasses? Need dental work?)
Compare student mutuals: HEYME, LMDE, SMENO, or bank insurances
Check if you qualify for CSS (Complémentaire Santé Solidaire) on Ameli
Choose a package (Hospitalization only, Basic, or Comprehensive)
Subscribe online by providing your Social Security Number and RIB
Link your Mutuelle to your Ameli account (Noémie system) for automatic refunds
Download your 'Carte de Tiers Payant' (allows you to not pay upfront in pharmacies)
tips: Ensure 'Télétransmission' (Noémie) is active so you don't have to mail paper sheets
Check if your parents' insurance covers you abroad before buying new one
Hospitalization costs are the biggest risk—ensure your plan covers 'Forfait journalier hospitalier'
The 'Responsabilité Civile' included in mutuelles is required for internships

title: Electricity Contract (EDF)
label: Utilities
description: Open an electricity meter account if you are renting a private apartment.
shortSummary: Required for lights, heat, and proof of address

detailedInfo.overview: If you rent a private apartment (not a CROUS room or shared facility where bills are included), you must open an electricity contract in your name. This bill is the 'Gold Standard' for Proof of Address in France.
detailedInfo.discussion: EDF (Électricité de France) is the historic provider, but you can choose competitors (Engie, TotalEnergies). However, EDF is the most recognized for administrative proofs. Most apartments now have 'Linky' smart meters, which means activation is remote and instant (no technician visit needed). You will need the PDL (Point de Livraison) number found on the meter or previous tenant's bill. Bills are usually estimated monthly and adjusted annually, or you can pay actual usage via the Linky data.
steps: Ask landlord for the PDL number (14 digits) or the name of the previous tenant
Take a photo of the meter reading (indexes) on move-in day
Go to EDF.fr or call their English-speaking line
Subscribe to a 'Tarif Bleu' (Regulated Tariff) contract
Provide RIB for monthly direct debit
Download the EDF app to track consumption
Download your 'Attestation de Contrat' immediately—this is your proof of address
requiredDocuments: PDL Number (Point de Livraison) or PRM
tips: Do this within 48 hours of moving in to avoid power cuts
The 'Justificatif de Domicile' (Proof of Address) from EDF is valid for 3 months and needed for Bank, Visa, and Prefecture
Linky meters allow you to see daily consumption—monitor it to avoid shock bills
When moving out, you MUST cancel the contract to stop paying
